block.p: Aetna Agrees to Sell Units To ING for $5 Billion in Cash Aetna agreed to sell its international and financial services units to the ING Group of the Netherlands for $5 billion in cash, people close to the deal said.

Under the deal, which was to be announced before the opening of the stock markets in Europe today, Aetna will create a new health care company that will keep the name Aetna. ING will also assume $2.7 billion of Aetna's long-term debt. [Page C2.]

Giveaway Music Pays Off for Some As the recording industry and commercial artists try to stamp out the distribution of copyrighted music for free in the form of computer files, tens of thousands of aspiring rock stars are happily using the technology to give their music away -- and more than a few are beginning to see some payoff. [A1.]

Top Two Airlines Beat Expectations Earnings at the nation's two largest airline companies, UAL, the parent of United Airlines, and AMR, owner of American Airlines, handily beat Wall Street expectations. But United also warned of weaker earnings in the current quarter, touching off a large sell-off of airline stocks, led by UAL, which fell $5.9375, or 10 percent, to $53.3125. [C6.]

I.B.M. Posts 12% Gain in Profit Despite declining sales, I.B.M. managed to surprise Wall Street with earnings of $1.9 billion for the second quarter, up 12 percent from results in the period a year earlier. [C4.]

House Passes Bill on 401(k) Plans In the latest action on big tax bills, the House overwhelmingly passed a measure that would increase the allowable level of tax-deductible contributions to individual retirement accounts and 401(k) programs. [A20.]

Broad Sell-Off Sends Gauges Down Investors sold technology shares to lock in profits, sending the Nasdaq composite down 121.54 points, or 2.9 percent, to 4,055.63. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 43.84 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,696.08, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slumped 11.78 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,481.96. [C7.]

Apple Overhauls Some Products Apple Computer introduced a flurry of products from a restyled mouse to an overhaul of its iMac desktop computers, whose sales have stagnated recently. Apple has enjoyed a remarkable revival the last three years under the leadership of Steven P. Jobs. But lately, industry analysts have pointed to signs that Apple's momentum may be slowing. [C4.]

Executives Urge Closing Digital Gap A group of high-technology executives urged the wealthiest nations to take action to erase a growing digital divide separating the developed and developing worlds. [A6.]
Trade Deficit Widened in May The trade deficit widened slightly more than expected in May, to a record $31.04 billion, as both exports and imports declined. [C19.]

Gas Use Down in First Half of 2000 The American Petroleum Institute said that deliveries of gasoline in the first half of 2000 were down about 0.7 percent, ending a long period of growth. The data also showed that supplies of heating oil were lower than usual. [C5.]

Effect of the Online Job Search The Internet is rapidly changing the way workers search for jobs and employers recruit workers. The resulting speed and ease of filling jobs have significant implications for unemployment, pay and productivity. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. [C2.]
